in pencil in top margin  [1983]   vine, Gene
- Dear Jack:  was re-reading past correspondence, your last card prompted this card.  Have been here in never-never land for a year and a half now, California three working on a script and a couple of pilot ideas.  Not a very friendly place Hollywood.  Been divorced for awhile now.  Visited w/ aldine last year when she was here.  never did get you the Jack Conroy Reader. but will soon.  never did get to meet the Sage of Moberly, but in spirit we travel together.  How is Gladys doing?
warmest, gene
Completed

bank check  THE PEOPLES NATIONAL BANK IN LAWRENCEVILLE   PAYABLE AT PAR THROUGH FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM   70-752/812
LAWRENCEVILLE, ILL.,  Any day 19__ No. My 1st
PAY TO THE ORDER OF  Jack "Toots" Conroy   $1,000.00
A Thousand Kisses & All my Love
"Fifi" Darling
Completed

Friday -  Third
Dear Vice President in charge of Bungling Things Up.

     Your delayed action letter inviting me up to see "Aunt Dorothy" while still alive, arrived today.  About Two weeks from text covered by mark on the pageTo those all for marks on page obscure text  Tis all for blurred  
     At any way ? made a Fast Trip to E. St. over Easter week-end to check on affairs down there.  Found only two conditions existing that I feel should be brought to your attention.   One depressing.  One enlightening.  First the sordid one.
    Buck Blue is recuperating from the ardors of a strenuous [sic] speech making campaign, wherein Dick Mahoney had the dubious honor of polling some 7,000 votes to be defeated by a 2-1 margin for the state legislature.  I suppose is [sic] is significant thought ? Dick is young & untiring, while the victors
Completed

Are men who take pauses  The prime of life and are on the way out of the political picture.   Blue was tired, worried, broke and perturbed about getting rid of some 19 yr old wench he has on ?/  He was overjoyed at the ? stuck stains on paper obscure the text  lover Than it broke until I tried to ? at midnight Monday.  ? for news of our ? & that viper Falto Alas, it ? very little of conditions in Chi & proved to be a poor source of info.  Cheered him up some ? when I promised to send some old scraps of letters from you to Muse over which I have Faithfully done.

    The second news item you will appreciate, I know.  ---  While on the East side, I decided to give Der Balch a ring.  Woe is me!  Ah death, where etc. -  What Folly!  How stupid of me.

in left margin  316 Mass - 316 Mass   - 316 Mass - 316 Mass  316
in right margin 316 Mass    316 Mass
Completed

The phone conversation you can fill in - As I give you the highlights in same.

    1st  He (After getting through a cordon of secretaries, identifying myself to each one), did not know any Walker.
   2nd   When I persisted - He (the cad) said he couldn't her me, as the phone was faulty
   3rd  After making sure I was Leaving AT midnight that same night, invited me to lunch with him on the morrow.
   4th  He was terribly busy, pleased that I called, did not receive that critical letter I wrote re:  opera review of his last summer, would I write again,  regards to my wife & kiddies, hello to you, if I saw you etc.

(Comment)

   By now I had spent twenty minutes time on my sisters phone bill.  She living out on the hill in St. Louis. (charges, approximately 35c)   Then I made the mistake
Completed

6th I mentioned I had heard he had written a play.  He spent the next 50 minutes telling me of "In Chalk, on the sidewalk."   "Are you sure you got that Walter," he asked.  " In chalk etc.     fold in paper and stains obscure text  Finally the operator said? up ? Eoi L & S.I. L. ?  phone calls at the Post Dispatch that she would also tell the online Bell System about "In Chalk on The Sidewalk" if Bro Dolan would stop yelling hysterical & screaming "In chalk etc" over the phone.

  Man, what an ordeal to go through.  I'll never make that mistake twice.
   Tell Fincho to drop me a line or make a little trip down here.  I'll see that he is supplied with plenty of booze.

Love & kisses
You are forgiven
Walker
Completed

Jackie Boy   your status with stains on paper cover text  ?ners yet.  But it was not to be had.  (Why don't obscured text often)? 

   Glad to hear you are not quite a tee-totaler as I plan on a gay time when I come up for my exam.  Can you arrange for a skirt to take care of a lonesome boy for one night underlined:  at least.   After all, if I pass won't I be Fighting for these virtuous (?) dirty little bitches so they won't be raped by the little yellow men and overrun our Fair cunt ry with a lot of cross breeds?
    Talked at some length with a Fellow last night who claims to have met "Bloody Balch" over at Salvo's place.  Franklin & Delmar or Franklin & Grand I thought.  Salvo is in the army and some rich old sport has his studio.  Evidently the Tavern is gone.  
    Any way this guy I know had a friend with him who must have tried to involve Balch in a few polemics but was met with smart rebukes.  After all (they tell me)  Balch made a swampeastern tour with
Completed

some movie stars in the interest of Uncle Sm and wrote 7 columns concerning same.  This guy that read it said 6 columns were about BALCH and an actress and the last about the actress.  Old modest retiring J.B. never changes.

   Haven't seen much or any of Wharton.  Saw the fair Jacqueline tother [sic] day and the land cruiser is tied up for repairs.   She isn't too reticent to go out with & give Wee  Willie a smell of that stuff of hers but she looks worried & harassed.  She mutters darkly of leaving our fair midwest for pars unknown after the war.  Says Doc Otty writes daily letters threatening to take her life if she ever even says "Hello" to another man.  Which probaly is ½ True.  Say nothing of my speculation about prospects of ass re: Jacky.
   Imagine I'll come up last of month or thereabouts.  Maybe Doc Blue will be willing to be coaxes into convoying me.     Bill     (write)

in left margin   P.S.  Your last letter was a masterpiece.  Will save same for posterity.       Bill Waller  595 Mo. Ave.  ℅ Century sign store   E. St. Louis Ill
Completed

paper folded over and stained obscuring parts of text
out to him because ? $2.80.  He financed ? of my projects to ? amount some time ? and before I make overtures to that worth ? I must arm myself w? that amount.  Not such an easy thing to do when you are clothing  [single underline:  3] boys.  The youngest 13 months, and come Sept and the rains we, rather Margaret, will see if we're in a rut or if maybe we're broken the spell & have a girl.
Completed

Would like very much to jaunt up The Windy City - but must find an angel first.  Preferably one with a new car & plenty cabbage.
    Have neglected writing B.B. so long I guess I'll just forget it.
    High school class of 1930 will have reunion 6-24-50 at K.C. Bldg. here & I was to extend invitation to B.B.  Believe he would disrupt entire party ?there? so I'll desist.  If you write him - mention it.

Best    Walker xxxxxxxxxx
Completed

page looks like it was soaked - ink is smudged and stains cover some areas
letterhead  THE STEVENS  Chicago  World's Largest Hotel
smudged  lines in top margin    unclear  what  unclear is in.  I'll write it in the bill the hotel - Illinois
Whores, pimps, grafters etc
Saturday the 8th
Evansville, Ind.
Dear Jack -- 

     I'm sending "Black Boy" under separate covering.  Hope  you like it.  I thought it only passably fair.  Have you called or seen LeVern yet?  do so, if you haven't - he's an "eight" guy.  Did I tell you he is taking this renewed friendship with the girl he met, while with us, seriously.  wouldn't be surprised if he didn't take a dive there.  Not a fallen dive however.
    The ? enjoyed meeting Hutcheson, but had a poet laureate lover of hers there who was quite boring.  She talked of you incessantly and finally dismissed the ? B.F. by telling him she & I had a date with the "Roney Heiress."  As you know, it was only an excuse while we were trying to trap the Fallon in his den.
    What news from Blue?  Is Fincho still living off the FAT (heads) of the land?  Maybe he will land an executive posish & be able to employ all his
Completed

page looks like it was soaked - ink is smudged and stains cover some areas
smudged several lines  continental damn.

  To the Reverend for spiritual guidance we have all dispaired of him ever being a man of Dick N. ? Ky. that, I refer to the size of the bankroll not ? work.  According to ?  Balek is the one now "most likely to succeed" but to isolation to be of any (commercial) value ?to his? erstwhile friends.
   Alas, and alack!  ? life goes.  ?   Am stuck away in southern Indiana with no bright prospects than slaving my ? ass off until my time is up.  My wife will probably keep conniving around and manuvering [sic] me into the mood that I'll finally consent to another baby.  ? disgust will set in and I'll try.  ? all other hoosiers and make a stab at having the largest family in Indiana, or sumpin.
   Write & let me know the nooze.

Love & kisses
Walker
P.S.  underlined:  Books?   Don't tell underlined: me anything about books, Conroy.
Completed

letterhead and footnote  Hotel Grand and Palmer  owned and operated by John F. and Patrick A. Carrico   Springfield, Illinois   two down town modern hotels   grand hotel  109 North 7th St  Phone  3-4618    Palmer Hotel  Jefferson at 5th St.  Phone  2-7707 - 2-7708   WHERE A GUEST IS AN INDIVIDUAL---NOT A NUMBER
Wed  after work -
Dear Rev -

    Just a short note to let you know of  your wandering boy's whereabouts.  Was mighty glad to hear your comforting voice & those words of wisdom from the old maestro.  This morning when I found out the call was only 1 96 I was happy that at least
Completed

letterhead and footnote  Hotel Grand and Palmer  owned and operated by John F. and Patrick A. Carrico   Springfield, Illinois   two down town modern hotels   grand hotel  109 North 7th St  Phone  3-4618    Palmer Hotel  Jefferson at 5th St.  Phone  2-7707 - 2-7708   WHERE A GUEST IS AN INDIVIDUAL---NOT A NUMBER
that much of this Fridays check was well spent.

    In my alcoholic stupor I forgot what you had to report on AllGreed.  Will you please drop me a line regarding him & B.B.
    Met a nice chick in E. St. L. some weeks ago & went home with her to Carbondale.  Nice house - stayed 2 days - plenty Budweiser - new Pontiac
Completed

letterhead and footnote  Hotel Grand and Palmer  owned and operated by John F. and Patrick A. Carrico   Springfield, Illinois   two down town modern hotels   grand hotel  109 North 7th St  Phone  3-4618    Palmer Hotel  Jefferson at 5th St.  Phone  2-7707 - 2-7708   WHERE A GUEST IS AN INDIVIDUAL---NOT A NUMBER
and good humping.  Spreading the fame of Conroy's around I found she was a very interested girl.  Would appreciate it if you would drop her a line or two to give her the pleasure of saying she had received a letter from a famous writer (author).

  Just say I'd been telling you of the hospitality,
Completed

letterhead and footnote  Hotel Grand and Palmer  owned and operated by John F. and Patrick A. Carrico   Springfield, Illinois   two down town modern hotels   grand hotel  109 North 7th St  Phone  3-4618    Palmer Hotel  Jefferson at 5th St.  Phone  2-7707 - 2-7708   WHERE A GUEST IS AN INDIVIDUAL---NOT A NUMBER
quality of beer - life in the country etc.

   Maybe you could do a carbon of it & let me know what to bullshit her about in my next letter.
   Do drop your Lonesome ol' pen pal a line.  Baby, I miss you so.

"Amber" Walker
P.S. Will be here 2 months.
OVER
Completed

Another with arrow pointing to Gladys
Miss Gladys Kirk
Box 223
Carbondale, Ill
Completed

Dear Rev --

   Have been neglecting my correspodence [sic] lately and feel it my bounden duty to keep you informed of my whereabouts, health. and financial status, (if any)
   Margaret and I are still battling along together.  Our family consists of 3 boys and 2 girls.  We don't get along sexually.
   She is teaching here in Henderson, while I lead the life of Reilly.   (How was Reilly's life, anyway?
Completed

Was reading last Thursdays Post Dispatch about some dude who was "Mr Little Theatre Himself."  There in he did mention the name of Jack Balch.  That guy is one of the Unholy Trio isn't he?  Bach, Beethoven & Balch.  Won't we ever escape him.
   Saw B.B. frequently this summer.  He was  on the wagon & I was tending bar.  Alas & Alack.  He was conducting a one man crusade against his employers.  The Cahokia Race Track Co.
Completed

He seems to have aged considerably.  Avoiding Wharton, me, if drinking, and acting as if he had galloping gleet or some other mysterious malady.
   Drop me a line as I often wonder about you & wonder when I'll get a chance to get to Chi again.
   What's with Algren?  The Golden Arm creating quite a controversy eh?  

Love & kisses    Walker
428 Cherry
Henderson, Ky.
Completed

Sun P.M.
Dear Doctor -

    Just a short line to let you know I see considerably of O'Fallon.  He's in the dumps.  I believe he's looking for a scabbing job.  He will be by tomorrow & I'm going to advise the "Pinkerton Agency", to him.  Might as well go all the way.
   I'm laid up with a broken ankle.  Be a month before I get back to work.  Moved back here from Lawrenceville.  Bud says Algren & Amanda were trying to go to Paree on a honeymoon.  did he get cleared on
Completed

his visa yet?

   Thinking seriously of writing for True Romance or something.  What is your advice Reverend?  Don't you think the name "Wilma Walker" will look good on a real sexy story?  Maybe I could qualify for a Conroy Fellowship.  Let me know how the wind blows in Chi.  

Love & kisses  "Walker"
570 Veronica
E. St. Louis, Ill.
P.S. "Lonsome [sic] & blue, Thinking of you"
Completed

1-28-44
General Dwight Conroy

   How are you "Toots" so you've been eluding me & at last I've found out where you live.  What is this 2866?  A love nest buried in the hustle & bustle of the windy city?  Dr. Blue tells me you haven't had a drink in 3 months.  Ulcers of the stomach?  Can't feature you driving along on a water wagon  Of course I've known all along that the W.C.T. U. gang would bend their every effort to stop  you
Completed

from luring innocent little boys to their ruin with "Old Demon Rum."

  When Buddy Boy, Texas Slim et al return to the big city they will be sorely disappointed to find you letting their banners drag the ground.   
   I've been in Ev. Ind shipyards the past year & returned here to answer my 1-A.  Will be a month before I leave though.  Then to to Ch. for a pre med exam.

Bill Walker
Write me 343 Mo Ave   E. St. Louis.  In   ℅ Century Cigar Store
Completed

Wed - 4 -17 - 46
Dear Doctor

     How goes it?  D.T. down here.  Am thinking of making a pilgrimage to the windy city on or about the 25th of this month.  Must enlist your aid, though, for the benefit of my employer.  Here is your part of the play.  Write me a letter Monday - so I'll receive same Wednesday of next week telling me of the serious illness of Aunt (?) (your choice) and you don't think she will last over   2 or 3 days.  If I want to see my beloved Aunt alive again I should come to Chicago post haste.  The letter I'll show to my boss if my round trip ride materializes.  A wealthy ex G.I. is my prospect.  We will take him over the jumps.  See if you can get Finch's address in the meantime.  Ditto
Completed

Algren.   Or did Nelson go with Doubleday?  Is Schulman out of the Army yet?

   Saw in W. Winchell's column where St. L. ? received rave notices & a 2 column spread from G. J. Walker.  Pretty good, eh?  Should assure area a good income for a long time to come.   Will he forget Slappy series now that he has hit, you think -  Why don't you muscle in on his R. Wright twas max's or somebody's coat tails & ride the comet to fame & fortune.  Damn - you know enough guys in the bucks to start pulling a few  your way just for the advice & benefit of your experiences you are able to provide them with.
   I'm going to start a $1 00 a week for Conroy promotion club here at the Tavern where I work.  Should get 5 members.  Look at the prospects.  Thousands of taverns.
Completed

Monday  18th - 46
Dear Doctor --

    You have your heating problems and I am having my troubles acting as Indian Doctor, Lawyer, chief etc.  In other words - both my boys have had measles the last week, my wife in an ill temper from the monthly inconveniences, and I topped everything by getting on a glorious binge last Friday P.M. - attended a bartender's ball and arrived home in a comatose condition sometime Sat A.M.
   Ah yes, it was a bad week at the Walker Tepee.  The only ray of light glimmering in all this darkness was rereading Conroy's especially concocted cocktail of the miseries of B.B.  His must be a hard life.  When do you expect the Chi city council to pass a resolution purging your otherwise fair city of that rascal?  He must be doing things to Dotty that Fincho overlooked or neglected to delve into.
Completed

Zebra Derby was 2nd on the best seller lists here 2 wks ago but suddenly dropped off.

   Get him to write something a propos in a copy and forward to me C.O.D.  You know, Silent Snake, Black Hawk etc.
   Did Nelse go with D.D.?  He should, unless he figures on free lancing.  Then the only sure thing he has is his 20 a week for a year from Uncle.
   Try and obtain Finch's address and Nelson's.  I'd like to drop them a line.
   I'm still bartending here.  About the most notorious spot in this city "The Liberty Bell."   Got drunk 2 days and got fired from The Linden Hotel, the last place.  Been at the "Bell" about 5 weeks, but doubt if I can hold out another 3.  You might see me in about a month as I plan a week-end trip to Hammond to re-instate by Boiler maker's card and go out on construction again this summer.

Best regard   Bill.
P.S.  Put in 4 requests for TSAC. here.
Completed

letterhead with drawing of 8-story hotel and footnote    250 Comfortable Rooms - Wonderful Beds - Moderately Priced Dining Room and Coffee Shop
crossed out:  Hotel LaSalle  South Bend, Indiana  Leonard Mennucci  President  and Manager
Air Conditioned Banquet Facilities
(over)
8-23-47    Wabash - Ind
Dear Rev -

    What do you make of the enclosed?  Obviously a forgery.  What steps shall I take?
    Fallon did me in - making me sleep on bars - in cars & at home - on the Floor.
    Advise him I'll turn this over to F.B.I.
    Regards L.W. End -  "No Comment"  Walker

Write 259 E. Maple - Wabash
Completed

Hold this check for evidence in court.  OR - settle out of court for $500.00.

   Cash on barrellhead [sic]

File:Drawing of head in an X - like a skull and crossbones
Walker
Completed

Joe Bakaler - violinist at English Inn (St Louis Symphony)
Michael Henry (John Kinnealy) reporter and former manager of WTMV-E. St. Louis now with Columbia chain Chicago
Byron Scott - Chief announcer WTMV and DRAMATIST
Harry Gibbs - no explanation necessary underlined: KSD
Dear Jack:

     Showed your letter to a friend.  Bill Hart - pianist at Ye Olde English Inn in Stock Yards here.  He wrote the above to see if you knew any.  He is a double wavy underline:  brown boy.  Not me - hurts too much.

Best  Walker
Completed

letterhead and footnote  250 COMFORTABLE ROOMS - WONDERFUL BEDS - MODERATELY PRICED DINING ROOM and COFFEE SHOP
HOTEL LaSalle  SOUTH BEND, INDIANA  LEONARD MENNUCCI PRESIDENT AND MANAGER   File:8-story hotel building; shield with La Salle in banner
Air Conditioned Banquet Facilities
May 29, 1947
Thursday P.M.
Jack -

    Can't make it Friday.  Boy - Larry (4 yrs) sick at home.  A pox of some kind.  Probably be up in 2 wks.
    Write me either ℅ Hotel - or 259 E. Maple St. Wabash.
     Sorry this is short - but in a hurry -

Walker
Completed

2-13-46
Indianpolis  Ind.
Dear Rev -

  Haven't heard from you in quite a spell.   Does the mighty ? still get about  Are his nimble fingers so aching & aged that no longer can he sit down to his Trusty ? & write an uplifting letter to one of he old graduates of "Conroy's Classic Cunt Course?"
   Sometimes I feel as
Completed

if you are developing a Balchian complex.  Heavens to Betsy!  The mighty Conroy sunk so low?

   LaVern Hutcherson was up for dinner last P.M.   Bought [sic] a beautiful Creole with him.  The one he met on 63rd the day we ate with him - remember?  They are going to be married (?) he says.
    She is a social worker for the City of Chi.
Completed

Has A.B: from ? & B.A. from U of Chicago.  Margaret liked her very much.  The Carmen & Co., is playing to ? here for 4 days.  Thence to Cin. Ohio & the east coast.  This Hutcherson has news clippings comparing him to Paul Robeson & N. Bledsoe - I dunno - he may go far.

    What news of B.B.?  Still on the academic kick?  When did you last see or here [sic] from Finch?  Has Algren got out yet?
Completed

Is Tommy still at My Field in Kansas?  I'm going to inactivate that damn place so he can get back to some of the Chicago stuff he's been going without.  More headaches for the old man!
   Has Blue or Mahoney been up lately?
   Loosen up "bo" & give me some news.  I'm developing a "purged" complex

Bill
Note new address   316 Mass. Ave  Indianapolis, Ind.
Completed

letterhead  File:Corner view of five-story building with cars parked in street alongside
HOTEL INDIANA  FIREPROOF SCHROEDER HOTELS SLEEP IN SAFETY  WALTER SCHROEDER PRESIDENT   WABASH INDIANA
HOTEL SCHROEDER  MILWAUKEE, WIS.   HOTEL LORAINE  MADISON, WIS.   HOTEL NORTHLAND   GREEN BAY, WIS.   HOTEL RETLAW  FOND DU LAC, WIS.   HOTEL DULUTH   DULUTH, MINN.  HOTEL ASTOR  MILWAUKEE, WIS.  HOTEL VINCENT  BENTON HARBOR, MICH.  HOTEL CALUMET  FOUND DU LAC. WIS.  HOTEL INDIANA  WABASH, IND.  HOTEL WAUSAU  WAUSAU, WIS.
2-w-47
Wabash, Ind.
Dear Doctor -

   Imagine my pleasant surprise, upon buying to-day's Sun, and reading one of the best reviews you have ever done.  And of a book by that worthy young Arthur "Mr  Nelson "Slats" Algren.  It was a beautiful, scintillating, pulsating piece of work you did, Doctor.  Now - does the book live up to your praises?  If so - send me one - ℅ this hotel - C.O.D.
   Am doomed to be stuck in this burg for 2 months.  It is
Completed

letterhead  File:Corner view of five-story building with cars parked in street alongside
HOTEL INDIANA  FIREPROOF SCHROEDER HOTELS SLEEP IN SAFETY  WALTER SCHROEDER PRESIDENT   WABASH INDIANA
HOTEL SCHROEDER  MILWAUKEE, WIS.   HOTEL LORAINE  MADISON, WIS.   HOTEL NORTHLAND   GREEN BAY, WIS.   HOTEL RETLAW  FOND DU LAC, WIS.   HOTEL DULUTH   DULUTH, MINN.  HOTEL ASTOR  MILWAUKEE, WIS.  HOTEL VINCENT  BENTON HARBOR, MICH.  HOTEL CALUMET  FOUND DU LAC. WIS.  HOTEL INDIANA  WABASH, IND.  HOTEL WAUSAU  WAUSAU, WIS.

deader than my last affair in Indianapolis.

    A letter from some of the Chicago gentry would be like a drink of water to a man dying of thirst.
    Kindly notify Finch, Wally, et al of my whereabouts.
    Tell Nelson to send along one of the complimentary copies and I'll be his Northern Indiana agent for him.
    Little does he know what it means to have Walker crusading for him - but you could wise him up.

Love & kisses To penny - Bill
Completed

one boy.  Going to bring the other up from Ev. Ind. shortly

   Going in to E. St. Louis over the 4th holiday.
   What gives with your new children's book?  Whatsa name?
    Has All green gone South yet?  Is B.B. still on the $ kick?  Lucky lad - that Fallon.
Completed

letterhead and footnote  250 COMFORTABLE ROOMS - WONDERFUL BEDS - MODERATELY PRICED DINING ROOM and COFFEE SHOP
HOTEL LaSalle  SOUTH BEND, INDIANA  LEONARD MENNUCCI PRESIDENT AND MANAGER   File:8-story hotel building; shield with La Salle in banner
Air Conditioned Banquet Facilities
May 27, 1947
Tuesday -
Dear Rev -

    As you have probably noticed by the address - I'm having no little difficulty in locating you.  Have written from So. B. to 6312 So. Green St., - only to have the letter returned.  Inasmuch as I have none of your letterheads with me I'm at a loss as how to locate you.
    Am temporarily in So. Bend on a boiler job at a brewery.  Gazooks!  "Nuff sed."
    Expect wife up here Fri P.M. and will proceed to Chicago on the South Shore Line.
Completed

letterhead and footnote  250 COMFORTABLE ROOMS - WONDERFUL BEDS - MODERATELY PRICED DINING ROOM and COFFEE SHOP
HOTEL LaSalle  SOUTH BEND, INDIANA  LEONARD MENNUCCI PRESIDENT AND MANAGER   File:8-story hotel building; shield with La Salle in banner
Air Conditioned Banquet Facilities

   Expect to do a little nite clubbing - There is a modest hotel and a little cutting with "My Favorite Blonde."
   Been busy as  hell in Wabash Ind.  In fact - I bought a house there and have settled there.
   We will leave here on the 9 30 train (So. S.) and go to the Randolph St. station.  Arriving around 11 45
   Will you contact Finch Fallon Algren et al and tell them I'd like to while a way a couple of hours with them digging up old times
   If you are not working Sat - meet me and we'll toss off a few.  Write me ℅ this hotel no later that Tursday.

Walker
Completed

letterhead  PLAZA HOTEL   FIREPROOF   JUST NORTH OF STATE CAPITOL   CAPITOL AVENUE AND NEW YORK STREET   Indianapolis, Indiana  File:Shield
1947
Friday P.M.
Dearest One -

    Your underlined:  Too letters came to-day.  Needless to say - I did leave a forwarding address from 316.  And you?  Well - anyway I now possess  your new number & know I can find a  warm bed & a hot meal any time I might journey north.  That  underlined:  could be next week-end.  I'm back in the berrly making racket because I have more time & kopecks to pursue the elusive sex.
    Don't believe I need to tell you I'll do my part of the promotion here for S.H.
Completed

letterhead  PLAZA HOTEL   FIREPROOF   JUST NORTH OF STATE CAPITOL   CAPITOL AVENUE AND NEW YORK STREET   Indianapolis, Indiana  File:Shield

   Trifle hard to sell it to the boys - but I may find a few war widows with bastard children who would like to chip off a couple for a worthy gent.
   What news of Blue?  When you write to Wally - give him my warmest.  "I luv that man."
    What has happened to Bonny Blue Boy Finch?  He promised me he'd be back afore the bells rang out.  No sign yet.

Love & kisses,
Yours
Completed

6-14-48
1731 S - 12th
Lawrenceville, Ill
Dear Rev -

    Been quite awhile since I've tackled a letter to you - but here goes!
    Working in Robinson Ill at the Marathon Oil Co. in a boiler job.  Will finish about September
     Living here in small apt with Margaret &
Completed

Will make an attempt to see Blue when I go in the 4th
  How is your family?  As usual I have no news to report.  Suppose I'm getting old & decrepit prematurely.
  Regards to Glady [sic] etc etc etc etc Penny arrow pointing both ways etc

Bill
Completed

letterhead  JONES HOTEL SYSTEM  AMERICAN PLAN  South Shore Inn  LAKE WAWASEE, INDIANA
LAKE WAWASEE, IND.  SOUTH SHORE INN    GREENFIELD, IND.  COLUMBIA HOTEL  U.S. ROAD        40  INDIANAPOLIS, IND.  SPENCER HOTEL  OPPOSITE UNION STATION
July 20the
Dear Reverend - 

    Your lackidasical [sic] attitude and evident apathy towards my repeated letters expressing my concern over the status quo have given me no small amount of anguish.  What provokes this attitude on your part is a matter I cannot ken!   Could it be the hand of a Chicago Balch?  Ah me, if I only knew.  Here is Walker - just a beachcomber on the shores of Wawasee, in the land of sky blue water, drinking and fucking himself to death.  Why?  Because I ma despised by everyone and forsaken by all my old friends.  Ah, death, etc.
  Here I have veritably another "Russ's Oasis" but no one to put on a "Drunkard's Warning."
Completed

letterhead  JONES HOTEL SYSTEM  AMERICAN PLAN  South Shore Inn  LAKE WAWASEE, INDIANA
LAKE WAWASEE, IND.  SOUTH SHORE INN    GREENFIELD, IND.  COLUMBIA HOTEL  U.S. ROAD        40  INDIANAPOLIS, IND.  SPENCER HOTEL  OPPOSITE UNION STATION

   Ah ye of little faith, Walker has fallen, it is true.  But true soldier that he is, "I shall return" and earn for myself the sobriquet "Douglas MacWalker."
    My queries regard "A World to Win" have not even received the courtesy of a reply.  Conroy, for shame.  What have I done to be treated like this?  Let me know, so I may make amends.  You have put another gray (gray, that is, not gay) hair in poor Walker's haid. [sic]

Lovingly Yours
Lonesome Willie
Completed

6/17/5?
Dear Rev:

     Just a few lines to let you know I'm alive and still kicking.  We are moving out of the city tis week-end to a farm place.  I'll only have 1 acre but that's enough for a few chickens, and a little garden.  Little did we know what changes 20 years bring.
    I tried selling for a while but the Jew bastard finally made it too tough for me.  Guess I'll go back to boiler busting in about a month.
    Saw The Golden Arm last night & thought of Algren.  How is he getting along?  By the by - How's B.B. too?  Haven't seen or heard of the gay young batchelor [sic] in about a year.  Is he still horse happy?
    Give my love to Glady & write soon.  May come up & see  you some day.  Gotta car again.   Ain't that nice.

Best
Squire Walker
arrrow pointing to address  R.R. 2 - Henderson, Ky
Completed

letterhead  JONES HOTEL SYSTEM  AMERICAN PLAN  South Shore Inn  LAKE WAWASEE, INDIANA
LAKE WAWASEE, IND.  SOUTH SHORE INN    GREENFIELD, IND.  COLUMBIA HOTEL  U.S. ROAD        40  INDIANAPOLIS, IND.  SPENCER HOTEL  OPPOSITE UNION STATION
Thursday -
Dear Rev -

     Here I am lolling around with the swells.  I don't mean those on the lake either.  Going to tend bar in the rathskeller over the week-end & then may stay longer.

Flash -

   Just entered into a contract with the boss & will stay the season - That's until Labor Day.  I get a small salary (room & board) commission and tips should be pretty good.  Figure to average 60 - 70 weekly  Maybe more - I hope so.
    Margaret & 2 boys are still in Indianapolis.  I had planned on making a pilgrimage to your city before starting here but a lost week in Indianapolis prevented that pleasure.  
    Regards to Fincho, B.B. et al.

Walker
Completed

    You will be glad to hear that Prof. Bowen is alive and well, living with his Ruthie in Tokyo and returning to U.S. this summer.  Enclosed touching tribute, in Japlish, was given to him by colleagues when he left Ushike.  "Being 68 years old "he will retire this fall, but he dreads it, poor boy.

letterhead   A A Wyn INC.  PUBLISHERS    23 WEST 47TH STREET - NEW YORK  36, N.Y.
August 23, 1954
Dear Jack:

    I was both pleased and terribly sorry to get your letter.  I can only begin to imagine how sad and upset you all were.  I never met your son - I think you and I were just stags foot loose in Chicago.  If I had though perhaps I could realize still more how you must feel.   The outsider is always so damnably helpless.
    London - where I have been for more than two weeks - is, as always, just marvelous.  The people are friendly, the food good and the city is, in spite of the horrible wet & cold weather, truly warm.  Have been too busy to wander down the narrow streets, browse in the book-shops and sit in the parks - but I've been here before and just love it.
    There aren't any geniuses that I know of but believe me - I'm looking.  Whether or not any books come out of this trip it will be worth while.  Get your hiking boots out & try that long walking tour.  Whether you need it or not England will make a new man out of you.
Completed

Please write me again.  I'll be back in New York on September   4.  I've told Larry about Tom - I do so much wish I could really do something for you -

Cordialy [sic]
Arthur Wang
Completed

letterhead  AUSTIN WARREN  DEPARTMENT OF ENGLISH, ANGELL HALL   UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, ANN ARBOR
home     507 Church St  Ann Arbor
20 October 1949
Dear Bro. Jack, -

     It did my sinquegenarian heart good to receive your admirable anthology with its lavish 'hand-written' inscription. - Now if you could only tell me where I could pick up the Great American Novel!  One of my favorite incidents out of the Yaddo fortnight is that which concerns 'the young' speaking of the GAN as something yet unrealized, & your speaking up with ? & manly dignity to say, "Why, I published that back in '28."
    That was a wonderful company at Yaddo this summer!  A great relief after the academic world.
Completed

You are quite mistaken, Bro. Jack, in thinking that you were an Ishmael.   You were one of the handsome reasons for the community's being what it was -

   We had a double W C Fields bill here at the University recently, to the delight of all.  I had the added delight of hearing Fields speak in the very voice & intonation of my friend Conroy. -
    I shall be coming to Chicago one of these week-ends on a visit, & shall hope that you can spare time to give me a temperance lecture. -

With warm regards,
Yours,
Austin
Completed

pencil in top margin  Austin
848, E. Univ. Ave
Ann Arbor
6 June 1963
Dear Jack, -

     I was much touched to hear from my old contemporary (we were both born in 1899) and to receive underlined:  The Disinherited,  I "rejoice with them that rejoice", as Scripture says; and I share your joy that your novel has been issued as an 'American Classic', or something of the sort:  anyway, issued with preface by one of those college professors who constitute a kind of Curia of Cardinals.
    Your book - not yet read - I remember in connection with 'Yaddo',  which after ten or twelve years, I expect to spend a month at this summer.  One day at dinner some novice of a creative writer raised the question of how come the Great American Novel had never been written; & you, without false humility or hesitation, immediately said, "It has been.  underlined: I wrote it in the 1930's".  I shall carry the book to "Yaddo" with me if I don't, before then, read it.
    When we were last together you gave me your wonderful anthology of Midwestern Humor.  I have often read aloud "The Harp of a Thousand
Completed

2
underlined:  Strings".  But the whole book is a favorite with me.  Recently I relished particularly the 'Arkansas Traveler' stories - especially Opie Read's "Chills & Fevers". - 

     Much has happened to me since we met.  My first wife, a Bostonian, died in Iowa City - though she is buried in Hebron, Connecticut, where I too, shall be buried.  In 1948 I moved to the Univ. of Michigan; & in 1958 I married another beautiful woman, - Antonia Degen, M.D., a German-speaking Swiss from Zurich.  She is - after the European mode - highly, humanistically read - unlike her American colleagues; has great happiness in her work as I do in mine.

With warm regards
from your old friend 
Austin
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Austin
"Yaddo"
19 June 1963
Dear Jack, -

     Yesterday I finished underlined:  The Disinherited, read in a day & a half.  What a painful, powerful book.  It made a deep impression on me, one which I shall never forget.   I can't bring myself to write a "literary" criticism of it;  yet it underlined: is literature:  it stays together, holds together, ends at just the right place, as he narrator walks off - or drives off in his flivver - from Monkey Creek and its specificities - into the crusade to make the revolution revolve, the Kingdom come.
    Wonderfully effective are the stanzas of poetry - or snatches of poetry, as they sometimes are (the two lines from Vachel Lindsay): the underlined:  work songs, the Irish ditto, even the stanza from Arthur Ficke. -
  Where do we go from here?

With deep gratitude,
Yours,
Austin
Where is Darkest Midlothian?  Is [sic] is a suburb of Chicago?   I gave a lecture at Iowa City a few months ago & stopped for a day at Chicago, which (like Iowa City) I hadn't seen for ten years.  Chicago has grown strikingly beautiful: 
in left margin   That is of course the part that a traveller sees:  the lake-front & that strange coil-shaped scraper of the sky.
Completed

greeting card  Sincere Wishes for a Joyous Christmas and a New Year of Great Happiness
in blue ink at bottom of card  AUSTIN WARREN
29 Dec 1964
Dear Jack, -

    It was a happiness to hear from you, tracts & all.
    The gigantic machine, the Univ. of Michigan, has gone onto a tri-semester schedule; so this is not only 2 weeks vacation but interval, between two rushed semesters.  I'm grateful not only for the rest but for the opportunity to write, which has always - in worst days - lifted me above the academic assembly line long enough so that I could go on.
    This morning I finished an essay; & some time today I'll resume work on underlined:  The New England Conscience, a book two-thirds written & already accepted for publication. - Like most of my writings, the conscience book has been written as a personal exercise in exorcism.

All the best.
Austin
Completed

Apt 2, 436 Prospect St.,
New Haven
Conn.  06511
Feb. 4th  1966
Dear Mr Conroy,

     Daniel Aaron gave me your address.  I am writing a book on William Carlos Williams, and part of it is concerned with his place in, or relationship with, the proletarian movement.   As you may know, he was very friendly indeed with Fred Miller of underlined:  Blast,  and was at least acquainted with the underlined:  Dynamo boys.  But I suspect you'll consider 'em all light-weights.  They hardly swung the hammer like you underlined:  Anvil fellows!
    I would be very grateful if you could tell me if Williams was ever in touch with you.  If you had any letters from him I would be extremely interested.  But in examining the issues of underlined:  The Anvil available to me here I can't find any contributions from Williams.
   I wonder if you can help me with something further.  Williams did receive a fair number of letters from H. H. Lewis, which I have seen in his correspondence.  Mr. Aaron can't tell me what has become of him.  I believe B. C. Hagglund was his publisher, and we can't find him either.  I wonder if you can help.  I strongly suspect that among Lewis' papers there should, in theory at least, be some damned enlightening letters from Williams.
    With very best wishes to you.  The younger generation (Im a 28 year old Englishman) salutes you.

Yours Sincerely,
Michael Weaver
Completed

Apt. 2, 436 Prospect Street,
New Haven,
Conn.  06511
Feb. 20th 1966.
Dear Mr. Conroy,

     Thank you very much indeed for your very kind and helpful letter about Williams and H. H. Lewis.  I knew about the underlined:  Partisan Review row, but there is so much I do underlined: not know, and I can imagine that the history of your own magazine is a fascinating, and complex, subject.
      Yale has seven issues of underlined:  The New Anvil as well as the original [[underlined:  Anvil) and I had already found the Williams stories in the first two issues.   Were there more than 7 issues of the underlined:  New Anvil, I wonder?   I would be extremely grateful to have copies of any letters Williams wrote to you, if you can unearth them.
      I wrote to Mr. Hagglund.  Thank you so much for his address.  He seemed pretty piqued about Lewis, though he did say that "that was all long ago."   Lewis, he said, defected towards the sound of Eastern applause.  His Williams letters, if he still has them might prove very interesting, so I may start enquiries in the Cape Girardeau area.
     I'm glad you enjoyed London.  You're right - the subway is unbeatable!
     Oh, and I nearly forgot, Fred Miller is still around, though an alcholic [sic] on the road mostly.   I haven't been able to find him.  I must say I like him; his letters, writings, have a boyish vitality, and fresh gusto.  I underlined:  have found the manuscript of an 80-page novel - short novel - on which he collaborated with Williams.  Very lively.  Many thanks for your help.   I'll certainly visit you if I can.  I've offered to do an
Not Started

essay on Williams and the Proletarian movement for David Madden's collection.   But there's a lot of work ahead of me.  There are a couple of things you may have answers for sometime  (Please don't trouble to reply unless something comes to mind):

   1.  Williams is said to have been one of the signers of the "Golden Book of American Friendship with the Soviet Union".  I'd be glad of details of this book (editor, place of publication, etc.)   1937, I think

2.  He is said to have signed a CP statement in 1940 demanding the end of the House Committee on Un-American activities.
3.  To have signed a public statement defending the policies and practices of the CP in 1941
4.  To have urged clemency for Earl Browder in prison in Atlanta in 1942
5.   To have spoken at a rally for three of the convicted "Hollywood Ten" just out of prison in 1951.  Paul Robeson was also billed to speak.
I  know underlined:  so much, but have not a single word of verification!  Maybe you've heard of some of these events or documents.
With very best wishes,
Mike Weaver
Completed

rubber-stamped address  37, West Garth Road,  EXETER, Devon, England.  Tel.  Exeter 73512
Dec 3rd  1967
Dear Jack,

      Here I am re-settled in England!   I am still working furiously on  the details of my William Carlos Williams book.
      Just before I left the U.S. of A I came across a puzzling episode in Williams' career, and I think you may have some information for me!  It seems his old friend Robert Carlton Brown established a community - the Llano colony - somewhere down in Arkansas or Tennessee.   It was to have supported itself on a find of oil, I believe.  Williams was interested in it.  I wonder if you would write me a letter telling me what you know about it.
    It is underlined:  said that Williams put $500.00 into the venture but couldn't get away from his practice to go down there.  I'm not sure of that.  But Brown was an old pal, and Williams was always hopeful of communes!
   When you come to England next please let me know.  We'll prowl around London together.

Best wishes,
Yours,
Mike Weaver
Completed

letterhead  OHIO VALLEY FOLK RESEARCH PROJECT  (an adventure in folk journalism)  The Ross County Historical Society, Chillicothe, Ohio
1/4/63
Dear Jack:

    I'm a damned heel not to have answered your letter and Christmas greeting sooner.  But now I have 11 grandchildren and my holidays were full of joy, work and fatigue.    too, I still have to work cam hard for a living and with age and heart-disease creeping up on this putrid old frame I have finally decided it might be good not to have to work for a living; but that is only a wicked dream, of course.
     Yes!  I'll do anything I can to promote THE DISINHERITED and with your permission I shall include a review in one of my underlined:  very humble folk publications.  If you can spare a copy I'll have someone here do a review and inasmuch I have 3 children at Ohio Univ branch here maybe they can introduce it some of O.U. English faculty.
  And, while our folk research project can not pa a cent for m.s. it would neverthe-less be a honor if we could somehow publish a Conroy piece in our series sometime. (an Ohio Valley background - about 8 pg double-spaced).

best wishes
Dave
Completed

I've written to see if he's still there.  After we get back to M.O. wd like to pay you a visit - or you down to New Orleans.  Wont be for 6 months yet - but could be 4.  Keep in touch -  Jon & Lou

letterhead  LOUJON PRESS  1009 East Elm   Tucson, Ariz.  85719
7/6/67
Dear Jack - Real good to hear from you.  Just nearly beginning to feel better.  Some damned scar strictures left but the Coleman dilator in my able surgeon's hands getting rid of them.  Yeah, I'd read in some mag you'd got the James L. Dow Award for Anyplace But Here.   Can't recall where - many congrats to you.  Lonny Goldberg wrote me awhile back you were there - & plugging the ?.  Thanks a lot!   Shouldn't be long now before we're able to
Completed

2
get the new (rebuilt) Heidelberg press to replace our broken-down one.  Those tracts  you sent best yet.  I enjoy them always.  Again, we're happy to hear of the award for the book.   Hope to see it someday.  Haven't heard from Ashley Buck for a month at least.  He's got a bad ulcer - & on a merciless diet.   Keep in touch --
Jon ( & Lou)
Completed

page torn from a magazine
[IMAGE:  woman's head with her chin resting on her fist and "OUTSIDER" printed across her forehead and covering her left eye]]  editors:  Jon & Louise Webb
footnote  1009  East Elm Street  Tucson  Arizona  85719
printed on the page  THE OUTSIDER goes into book format with Number 4-5, a big double issue; will henceforth be an Annual Documentary of vitally valid writing, poetry & prose - no taboos - from all creative schools & cliques in the U.S. today - and some from Abroad.  It is now at our press, being printed a page at a time in handset Baskerville, & will be exquisitely handbound; the size: 7 by 10.  In this initial book-issue will be a large section in homage to Kenneth Patchen, with many photos, & intimate tributes to KP from Rexroth, Ginsberg, Norman Thomas, Ferlinghetti, Norse, Bro. Antoninus, Eckman, J.B. May, Yates, Corrington, Combs, others.  so far, close to 500 Coll., City and U. Libraries have ordered this ltd. ed. book issue.
handwriting under the printed material
7/3/68
Dear Jack - Did you ever know or meet Patchen.  We need a few more pieces on KP for the Patchen sectin - personal, not any critical analysis of his stuff.  enclose proof of the one by Norman Thomas to let you  get idea of kind of stuff we want.  Perhaps a conversation wit him - or such.  And no sticky stuff - N.T. almost got sticky - but knew when to stop. - Shit, I got to go back for more prostate
Completed

surgery - biopsy - passed a few blood clots this week.  May be nothing but have to go thru same as the prostate removal routine.  On July 15.

    We're going fine with Outsider 4/5.  Hope I don't have to lose much time at hosp.
     On Patchen pieces - 3 or 4 paragraphs to a couple typed pages - & deadline end July - or a bit later.

Let's hear.
Love from us
Jon (& Lou)
Completed

letterhead  Loujon Press  1009 East Elm, Tucson, Arizona  85719  jon and louise webb, editors  THE OUTSIDER
7/21/68
Dear Jack - Just home from hosp.  No cancer.  They explored & discovered recurrence of prostate in "middle lobe" - & so I had to undergo same routine surgery - trans-urethral - as last year.  Prick sore as hell & will burn on each pissing for weeks - but I'll soon be back to full-time work here.

    Sure enjoyed the article
Completed

from MLa Quarterly - took me back to when - thanks much for it.

    Yes, hope you can do at least a typed page for the Patchen section.  Let me know.
     Know John Weston at poetry center - but not Bob Ramsey.
     Bukowski still slowly killing himself drinking - but keeps writing.  Will have about 5 pages his poems in Outsider 4/5.
     Ashley wrote excited letter couple months ago about going to live in New Orleans.  No word since.  Excuse the scribbling.  

Love from us   Jon (& Lou)
Completed

8/14/68
Dear Jack - Thanks much for the Patchen piece - it's okay - & will use it - (if paper stock lasts - & somehow I feel it will) - some lost in flood, I find.  Lou is recovering bit by bit - & I'm all right.  Am sending "The Story of the Forgotten Nail" tract to Bukowski - who drinks a lot.
Best to you   Jon (& Lou)

Dear Jack - Thanks for Xmas Card.  Yes, we're almost done on 4/5.  Used your piece, tho had to cut a bit to fit in.  Issue be at least 184 pages.  Going day & night to get done by end year on printing.  Will send you one of first copies to go out.  Be a big binding job.  Don't know how we made it ?  after our flood here.  ?  Jon (& Lou)

Dear Jack & Gladys -
Thank you for nice letter for my darling.  I am still here in Nashville, but am having mail go to My sisters house in Euclid, O.  It Seems that I should have not Signed 2 papers at once at Hospital, one for autopsy, other for giving body to Medical Scool [sic].  Having problems - But am having an ad come out in Village Voice - will send you one  Love - Louise
